results.description: Cartoons and anime are known for their dynamic and vibrant visuals, but beneath the cuteness they can also deliver powerful environmental messages and address the climate crisis.

key_work.title: NUTS
key_work.brief_description: The quaint and contemplative nature of walking simulator NUTS is expressed in the vibrant, Risograph-like print style. The game takes a darker turn when the player realises that shady developers are using the endangered squirrel’s behaviour patterns to assess the site of a proposed dam.

The event also inspired feature films that are part of a long tradition of disaster films, which often push the boundaries of VFX.

links.description: Twister is a formative example of the cli-fi genre, made in 1996, it paved the way for films such as Snowpiercer . Set in Oklahoma, Twister , sees a couple on the verge of divorce, have to set their marital issues aside to combat a series of highly destructive tornadoes and save the day.

results.name: Retrofuturism: aesthetic impact of space design on screen culture

end.title: Barbarella [DVD]
end.creator_credit: Roger Vadim, Dino De Laurentiis, De Laurentiis Entertainment Group and Marianne Productions
end.brief_description: This cult film by New Wave director Roger Vadim begins with a flawlessly executed zero gravity strip-tease by the film’s feisty 41st century space adventurer, Barbarella (Jane Fonda). The adventure begins when the president of Earth contacts Barbarella for her help in locating Durand Durand (Milo O’Shea), a young scientist who has vanished with a deadly positronic ray that contains the power to “shatter the loving union of the universe”. Her mission takes an unexpected twist after her fur-lined vessel makes a forced landing on the icy planet Lythion after being rocked by a magnetic disturbance. Barbarella soon faces a number of challenging situations that result in many costume changes, and pleasurable encounters with the handsome men who assist her as she continues to track the elusive Durand Durand. With the help of the angel, Pygar (John Phillip Law), Barbarella must infiltrate the city of SoGo and battle the Black Guards and the Great Tyrant - a sadistic seductress who wants Barbarella for her own devious purposes - to recover the devastating weapon and restore peace and order to the galaxy. Based on the French science-fiction comic by Jean-Claude Forest, with dazzling and inventive costume design by Jacques Fonteray and Paco Rabanne.

links.description: While Aelita follows a male cosmonaut travelling to Mars and freeing its people, in Barbarella, Jane Fonda plays a woman astronaut who travels back in time from the 41st century to save Earth. It was influential in the depiction of feminist narratives.

end.title: The Girl from Tomorrow. Ep 1-3
end.creator_credit: Kathy Mueller, Noel Price, Film Australia and Nine Network
end.brief_description: Alana, a lively 13 year old from the year 3000, finds herself stranded in a strange and primitive world when a time-travel experiment goes terribly wrong. She is kidnapped by Silverthorn, a fugitive war-lord from the dangerous and violent times of the year 2500 and they crash land in a rubbish dump in Sydney in the year 1990. Alana crawls from the battered time capsule, leaving Silverthorn unconscious, and escapes with her personal wrist computer P.J. as her only companion. Cold, hungry and frightened, she is discovered by Jenny, a rebellious purple-haired girl her own age and Petey, Jenny’s science fiction obsessed younger brother.

end.title: The Creator
end.creator_credit: Gareth Edwards
end.brief_description:
“What if that technology from the ’90s just went in a different direction, and we still used very tactile equipment?” – Production designer James Clyne

The Creator (2023) presents a future where humans and AI ‘simulants’ are at war. Set in 2070, 15 years after a nuclear explosion destroys Los Angeles, the film explores how technology and humanity struggle to coexist. The movie draws inspiration from classic sci-fi like Blade Runner (1982) and Akira (1988) and the anti-war message of Apocalypse Now (1979). The Creator uses vivid world-building to merge cyberpunk and retro-futurist styles with themes of conflict and coexistence.

The story follows Joshua (John David Washington), a soldier with cybernetic prosthetics who must destroy a new AI weapon. In New Asia, where people live peacefully with AI, Joshua discovers that the weapon is a simulant child, who he names Alphie (Madeleine Yuna). Through his growing bond with Alphie, Joshua confronts his own biases, realising that peace between humans and AI is possible.

The Creator combines futuristic landscapes with existing cultures, reflecting fears of both nuclear war and artificial intelligence. In this future vision, technology and humanity find a path to peace.

Retrofuturism in character and prop design
The Creator’s robots have an insect-like design (see the robotic monk on the left), but the AI simulants are the emotional heart of the film. Though they have human faces, the backs of their heads are a mechanical mix of human and machine. This design is retrofuturism – a style that blends old and new technology, with a focus on physical, hands-on elements. Props like Alphie’s game console and translator look like they’re from an alternate version of the 1980s or 1990s. Retrofuturism gives the film a timeless look and creates a nostalgic, human feel that contrasts with the idea of a sleek, perfect future.

World building in The Creator
Director Gareth Edwards and designer James Clyne created a detailed sci-fi world by mixing futuristic ideas with real places. Clyne took photos of locations in Asia and added sci-fi elements, sometimes turning local people into AI characters called ‘simulants’. They decided who became a simulant during the editing process after filming. This let them film quickly using handheld cameras, giving the movie a fast-paced action style.

Similarly to Tomboy, the slightly older teenage characters grapple with ideas of queerness, trauma, substance dependence and ruptures in family, friendship and romantic relationships.

end.creator_credit: Pete Docter, Ronnie del Carmen, Jonas Rivera, Pixar, Walt Disney Pictures, Ralph Eggleston, Josh Cooley, Meg LeFauve and Andrew Jimenez

video_links.name: INSIDE OUT | Trailer 2 - UK | Official Disney UK
INSIDE OUT | New UK Trailer | Official Disney UK

end.brief_description: Growing up can be a bumpy road, and it’s no exception for Riley, who is uprooted from her Midwest life when her father starts a new job in San Francisco. Riley’s guiding emotions— Joy, Fear, Anger, Disgust and Sadness—live in Headquarters, the control centre inside Riley’s mind, where they help advise her through everyday life and tries to keep things positive, but the emotions conflict on how best to navigate a new city, house and school.

constellations_other.name: From the outside looking in
constellations_other.description: In Marshmallow Laser Feast's Evolver, we journey inside the human body, inhaled through the lungs and swept throughout the cells with breath. Across screen culture, many narratives similarly explore what's under our skin.

constellations_other.name: Houses that move us
constellations_other.description: Our homes are important to us. When they’re good, they’re our havens. If that home changes, or things go wrong, it can affect us very deeply. This constellation looks at the different ways directors and game devs have positioned the home onscreen - from sanctuary, to hostile enemy.

links.description: Inside Out and Unpacking both centre around a young woman who we learn about through their journey of moving house. In Inside Out each of the main character’s emotions are embodied as individual characters to help illustrate the complexities of moving to a new city.

end.brief_description: A French family moves to a new neighborhood with during the summer holidays. The story follows a 10-year-old gender non-conforming child, Laure, who experiments with their gender presentation, adopting the name Mikäel.

links.description: Céline Sciamma’s Tomboy is framed by moving house. Ten-year-old Laure, who is gender non-confirming, moves to an apartment on the outskirts of Paris during the summer. Laure, who adopts the name Mikael, confronts formative ideas of gender expression, approaching teenhood and the complexity of friendships.

start.title: Storyboarding in Unpacking
start.brief_description: Part block-placing puzzle, part house decoration game, Witch Beam Games’ Unpacking is an intimate coming-of-age tale that maps the life of an unseen protagonist by asking the player to unpack her house each time she moves.

video_links.name: Toy Story Trailer 1995 | Disney Throwback | Oh My Disney

end.brief_description: Led by Woody, Andy’s toys live happily in his room until Andy’s birthday brings Buzz Lightyear onto the scene. Afraid of losing his place in Andy’s heart, Woody plots against Buzz. But when circumstances separate Buzz and Woody from their owner, the duo eventually learns to put aside their differences.

constellations_other.name: Flipping through the evolution of animation
constellations_other.description: Animation has come a long way since flip books were popular. These optical toys gave the illusion of movement, but now whole films and special effects are animated entirely through computers.

links.description: Toy Story is an animated classic which, while framed through the lens of toys that come to life, and similar to Unpacking is centered around the process of packing, moving, the intimacy of personal and domestic objects and what we can glean from the characters through their possessions.

links.description: Iconic cyberpunk film, Tron has greatly influenced the visuals of much screen culture since. The use of neon lights in particular are a direct reference for cyberpunk games like Umurangi Generation.

start.title: Akira [DVD]
start.creator_credit: Katsuhiro Otomo, Ryohei Suzuki, Shunzo Kato and Akira Committee
start.brief_description: Akira is set in Neo-Tokyo, 2019. The city is rebuilding after World War III. Kaneda and Tetsuo, two high-school dropouts, are members of a joy-riding motorcycle gang. They stumble upon a secret government project to develop telekinetic humans, apparently for use as weapons. The most powerful of these subjects is Akira, a being shrouded in mystery. The film is based on the popular graphic novel of the same name, which has achieved cult status in Japan. Animation and visual effects are outstanding in this spectacular and often disturbing vision of urban apocalypse. NB: THIS IS NOT A CHILDRENS’ FEATURE AND IS RECOMMENDED FOR MATURE AUDIENCES.

key_work.title: Gorr the God Butcher costume and sword
key_work.brief_description:
Gorr the God Butcher’s (Christian Bale) monochromatic, greyscale skin and clothes stand in stark relief to the larger-than-life, cartoonish colours of the gods’ outfits in Thor: Love & Thunder. Dressed in simple draped fabrics, Gorr the God Butcher’s outfit doesn’t offer any hints about his mysterious backstory – but the contrast does mark him visually as the film’s antagonist.

Creature and prosthetics designer Adam Johansen had the challenge of designing the prosthetics for Gorr, balancing simplicity with monstrosity. “Gorr is completely grey with multiple colours within that grey,” Johansen said. “For his monster look, we covered up his eyebrows and gave him heavier brows, teeth, full nails, veining and scarification. I’d go in and give him black goo to knock out all the pinks in his mouth and on his tongue.”

results.name: Swords, sandals and lightning bolts
results.description: In Thor: Love and Thunder, Russell Crowe plays one of the most recogniseable gods in the pantheon – Zeus. His scenes lampoon his Oscar-winning role in Gladiator, one of the most recognised films in a classic genre.

key_work.title: Zeus costume and lightning bolt
key_work.brief_description:
Thor Love and Thunder introduces Russell Crowe as Zeus, the legendary king of the gods. Like Thor (Chris Hemsworth), Zeus’ hero armour is bold and bright, emphasising his supernatural qualities. His burnished gold breastplate and swaggering confidence make it clear that he is a god who is used to being admired – perhaps a bit too used to it.

Unlike Thor, Zeus has been filling his days with excess, basking in the attention of the lesser gods in the Grand Pantheon, seemingly unmotivated to track down Gorr the God Butcher (Christian Bale). While his hero armour looks heroic on the battlefield, in the context of his decadent, easy lifestyle at the start of the film, the extravagance makes him look less like a living legend, and more like a man who is resting on his extremely golden laurels.

Chris Hemsworth (Thor) commented that he never thought he’d see Crowe on screen ‘with hints at Gladiator imagery, yet with a wink’.

end.title: The Fall of the Roman Empire
end.creator_credit: Anthony Mann, Samuel Bronston and Samuel Bronston Productions
end.brief_description: In second century Rome Emperor Marcus Aurelius plans to make the heir to the throne his adopted son Livius, rather than his biological son Commodus. Indignant with rage, Commodus has his father murdered and succeeds him, declaring himself a God. When Commodus discovers that his sister, Lucilla has a stronger claim to the throne than he, Commodus sentences her to burn at the stake. This sword-and-sandal epic harked back to successful 1950s biblical dramas with its lavish sets, scores of extras, remarkable action sequences and a chariot race. The exorbitant cost of the film (and poor audience reception) financially ruined producer Samuel Bronston. It has been speculated that audiences were tiring of such lavish productions and timing may have also hurt the film’s box-office - it was released the same year as the opulent Burton/Taylor epic “Cleopatra”. Cast includes Sophia Loren, Christopher Plummer, Alec Guinness, Omar Sharif and James Mason.

constellations_other.name: Swords, sandals and lightning bolts
constellations_other.description: In Thor: Love and Thunder, Russell Crowe plays one of the most recogniseable gods in the pantheon – Zeus. His scenes lampoon his Oscar-winning role in Gladiator, one of the most recognised films in a classic genre.

links.description: While many people recognise the influence of Spartacus on Gladiator, it also owes part of its plot to The Fall of the Roman Empire, which similarly follows a power struggle following the death of emperor Marcus Aurelius.

end.title: Monty Python's life of Brian [DVD]
end.creator_credit: Terry Jones, John Goldstone and HandMade Films
end.brief_description: Iconic comedy from the Monty Python team, “The Life of Brian” ridicules Christianity, organised religion, politics, underground subversives and Jesus Christ. From birth, the unfortunate and guileless Brian is mistaken for the Son of God and dogged by his nearby presence as well as being pestered by his shrewish mother. The Monty Python crew each play numerous roles within the film, creating an anarchic madcap spoof of Biblical films and religious epics. With several musical interludes, including “Always look on the bright side of life” (sung at the crucifixion) the writers slay many sacred cows in the name of comedy. Blissfully sacrilegious and completely irreverent, “Life of Brian” was banned in several countries, but nevertheless garnered cult status and is regarded by many as the funniest of the Monty Python’s feature films. Also features Spike Milligan and Beatle George Harrison, whose company produced the film.

links.description: The climactic scene of Spartacus features the recaptured slaves claiming “I’m Spartacus!”, when asked to identify the gladiator leader. The famous line was inverted and parodied in Monty Python’s Life of Brian, where captured prisoners claim, “I’m Brian!” to be pardoned.

links.description: Life of Brian was considered blasphemous by many and banned in some countries for its parody of Christianity. Biblical epics, like Samson and Delilah, ironically gained popularity during the mid-20th century by using biblical stories to include violence and sensuality to bypass Hollywood censors.

end.title: Conan the Barbarian
end.creator_credit: John Milius, John Bloomfield, Buzz Feitshans, Raffaella De Laurentiis, Estudios Churubusco Azteca S.A., Pressman Film, The De Laurentiis Company, Universal Pictures, Ron Cobb, Oliver Stone and Edward Summer
end.brief_description: A film adaptation of the classic sword and sorcery hero, Conan the Barbarian. A horde of rampaging warriors massacre the parents of young Conan and enslave the young child for years on The Wheel of Pain. As the sole survivor of the childhood massacre, Conan is released from slavery and taught the ancient arts of fighting. Transforming himself into a killing machine, Conan travels into the wilderness to seek vengeance on Thulsa Doom, the man responsible for killing his family. In the wilderness, Conan takes up with the thieves Valeria and Subotai. The group comes upon King Osric, who wants the trio of warriors to help rescue his daughter who has joined Doom in the hills.

end.title: The Bushido blade
end.creator_credit: Tom Kotani, Arthur Rankin Jnr, Bass, Rankin-Bass Productions and Trident Films
end.brief_description: A co-production between the US and the UK, “The Bushido blade” is set in Japan in 1854 at the time when Commodore Matthew Perry (Richard Boone in his last film role) and his men sailed from the United States on a mission to Japan to sign a treaty uniting the two nations. As a sign of goodwill, the Shogun was to pass on the sacred Bushido Blade to Commodore Perry as a gift for the President of the United States but the Treaty would not be signed by the Japanese until the sacred sword was in Perry’s possession. To the Japanese, the Bushido Blade is a national symbol of the old ways, the Samurai tradition, and it has been this way for centuries. In the Shogun’s Commander’s (Toshiro Mifune) words “The sword is of spiritual character…Samurai warrior should live and die, sword in hand”. However, during the course of events, and just before the Treaty is to be signed, the Bushido Blade is stolen by a group of Samurai warriors opposed to the treaty and from there on in the remainder of the film is dedicated to the return of the blade. Based loosely on historical facts, the film proved to be a disappointment on release probably due to the low budget, poor scripting and not enough action (too much of the comedy and romance for dedicated fans of Japanese warrior films). It was eventually reissued under the title “The Bloody Bushido”. Cast also includes Sony Chiba, Laura Gemser, Frank Converse, James Earl Jones, Mako, Mayumi Atano, Timothy Murphy, Michael Starr.

links.description: Actor Toshiro Mifune worked with Akira Kurosawa on 16 films across two decades, including Seven Samurai. Known for his magnetic, expressive performances, he also had success in Western cinema, starring as Commodore Akira Hayashi in The Bushido Blade.

end.title: Star Wars
end.creator_credit: George Lucas, Gary Kurtz, Lucasfilm, Ltd. and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
end.brief_description: A Long time ago in a galaxy far far away, George Lucas’s space adventure captured the hearts and imaginations of film lovers of all ages from the moment these words scrolled across the screen. The Empire’s evil Death Star must be destroyed. The heroes, Luke Skywalker, Princess Leia, Han Solo and a pair of droids named R2-D2 and C-3PO, as part of the Rebel Alliance, must pit their strength against the might of the Empire and the evil Jedi, Darth Vader. With the help of an old Jedi Knight, Obi-Wan Kenobi, they battle the forces of darkness and triumph. The special effects and famous “Star wars” theme music has ensured that this film takes its place in cinema history. Includes a ten minute interview between George Lucas and Leonard Maltin.

end.title: World of Warcraft
end.brief_description:
Four years have passed since the aftermath of Warcraft III: Reign of Chaos, and a great tension now smolders throughout the ravaged world of Azeroth. As the battle-worn races begin to rebuild their shattered kingdoms, new threats, both ancient and ominous, arise to plague the world once again. World of Warcraft is an online role-playing experience set in the award-winning Warcraft universe. Players assume the roles of Warcraft heroes as they explore, adventure, and quest across a vast world. Being “Massively Multiplayer,” World of Warcraft allows thousands of players to interact within the same world. Whether adventuring together or fighting against each other in epic battles, players will form friendships, forge alliances, and compete with enemies for power and glory. A dedicated live team will create a constant stream of new adventures to undertake, lands to explore, and monsters to vanquish. This content ensures that the game will never be the same from month to month, and will continue to offer new challenges and adventures for years to come.

This game has a monthly online fee. Adventure together with thousands of other players simultaneously. Explore an expansive world with miles of forests, deserts, snow-blown mountains, and other exotic lands. Join the Horde or the Alliance as one of 8 playable races. Select from 9 classes, including holy Paladins, shape-shifting Druids, powerful Warriors and Mages, demon-summoning Warlocks, and more. Encounter many familiar and new Warcraft characters and monsters. Learn the continuing story of Azeroth by completing a wide variety of challenging quests. Journey through an epic world filled with dungeons of different styles and depths. Explore 6 huge capital cities, which serve as major hubs for the races inhabiting them. Practice various trade skills to help locate reagents, make and enhance custom items, acquire wealth through trade with other players, and more. Purchase tickets for travel along a number of air routes flown by creatures such as Gryphons and Wyverns. For global transportation, travel by Boat or Goblin Zeppelin. Once a certain level has been achieved, players can choose to purchase permanent personal mounts, such as Dire Wolves and Horses. Establish a guild, purchase a custom guild tabard, and promote or demote recruits to different ranks within the guild. Locate and engage other players with easy-to-use features and tools, including chat channels, friends lists, and animated and audible character expressions. Customize the game’s interface via XML. Enjoy hundreds of hours of gameplay with new quests, items, and adventures every month.

results.name: Processing grief through art
results.description: Thor: Love and Thunder begins with Thor meditating in a robe designed by Gumbaynggirr/Bundjalung artist Otis Hope Carey, best known for Ngalunggirr miinggi (healing spirit) (2020), a painting that expresses his grief over the loss of grandmother. Many artists process grief through their creative work.

key_work.title: Thor meditation robe costume
key_work.brief_description:
Thor: Love and Thunder isn’t just a heroic adventure – it’s also the story of Thor’s (Chris Hemsworth) personal growth. At the outset, Thor is processing his grief following the events of Avengers: Endgame (2019). During a period of self-reflection, he meditates in a robe that features a design by Gumbaynggirr / Bundjalung artist, Otis Hope Carey.
Hope Carey’s paintings are immediately recognisable for the way they refigure and adapt traditional Aboriginal art styles and symbols. His work also speaks to the emotional themes of the film directly: his work is deeply invested in spirituality, mental health, and connection to community and Country. In 2020, his work Ngalunggirr miinggi (Healing Spirit), which tells the story of the passing of his grandmother, was nominated for the Art Gallery of NSW’s Wynne Prize.

constellations_primary.description: Thor: Love and Thunder begins with Thor meditating in a robe designed by Gumbaynggirr/Bundjalung artist Otis Hope Carey, best known for Ngalunggirr miinggi (healing spirit) (2020), a painting that expresses his grief over the loss of grandmother. Many artists process grief through their creative work.

end.title: Malcolm
end.creator_credit: Nadia Tass and David Parker
end.brief_description: Malcolm, a simple genius played by Colin Friels, loses his job at a Melbourne tram depot after building his own one-man tram and taking to the streets. With funds dwindling, Malcolm is forced to take in a lodger, a small time criminal who moves in with girlfriend, Judith. Frank soon realises that Malcolm’s mechanical wizardry can help his career - the result - a series of oddball but unsuccessful robberies that culminates in the heist of the decade that stretches Malcolm’s devices to the full. “Malcolm” was critically acclaimed worldwide and received eight AFI Awards including best director and best film.

links.description: Like Thor: Love and Thunder, Australian indie film Malcolm is a quirky, comedic romp with heart. The film is dedicated to director Nadia Tass’ late brother, John, who inspired the titular character.

start.title: Amy
start.creator_credit: Nadia Tass
start.brief_description: Amy’s father, Franco, was a popular rock musician accidentally electrocuted while performing on stage. The psychological trauma leaves Amy mute and deaf. So the 8-year-old is brought by her mother, Tanya, to Melbourne to diagnose the reasons for her continued silence.

links.description: In the same year that Amy was released, Elton John expressed the cultural grief over the death of Princess Diana by performing a rewritten version ‘Candle in the Wind’ from Goodbye Yellow Brick Road at her funeral.

end.title: Spiritfarer
end.brief_description: Spiritfarer is a cozy management game about dying. You play Stella, ferrymaster to the deceased, a Spiritfarer. Build a boat to explore the world, then befriend and care for spirits before finally releasing them into the afterlife. Farm, mine, fish, harvest, cook, and craft your way across mystical seas. Join the adventure as Daffodil the cat, in two-player cooperative play. Spend relaxing quality time with your spirit passengers, create lasting memories, and, ultimately, learn how to say goodbye to your cherished friends. What will you leave behind?

Many artists process grief through their creative work.

links.description: Musical tributes like ‘Candle in the Wind’ can help us process grief – and so can videogames. Spiritfarer is a gentle, meditative game about the afterlife, giving a player the opportunity to help a lovable cast of ghostly characters find their final peace.

links.description: Malcolm draws from director Nadia Tass’ own life, but it’s not her only film about grief. Amy tells the story of a girl who becomes mute after the traumatic death of her father, able to communicate only through song.
